choices.text: B/l tubal block

questions.text: What is your interpretation of the following hysterosalpingogram?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Submucosal fibroid

 

Explanation:

 

  • This HSG shows a large well defined lesion in the uterus.
  • This is most likely a submucosal fibroid

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. Normal: A normal HSG would show a regular, symmetrically shaped uterine cavity without any filling defects or irregularities. The fallopian tubes would be visible, with the contrast material flowing freely through them, indicating patency . No obstructions or unusual shapes should be present.

 

Option B. Asherman syndrome: This condition is characterized by the presence of intrauterine adhesions or scar tissue. On an HSG, Asherman syndrome may present as irregular filling defects within the uterine cavity or as a generally diminished size of the uterine cavity, depending on the severity of the adhesions.

 

Option C. Bilateral tubal block (B/l tubal block): In cases of bilateral tubal blockage, an HSG would show a lack of contrast material passing through one or both fallopian tubes ie. absence of free spill.

 

Option D. Submucosal fibroid: They are fibroids that grow just beneath the lining of the uterine cavity. On an HSG, these would appear as filling defects within the uterine cavity. They might show as smooth, round, or lobulated contours projecting into the cavity, disrupting the otherwise smooth and regular shape of the uterus.

 

Educational Objective: HSG is a valuable diagnostic tool in assessing the shape of the uterine cavity and the patency of the fallopian tubes, which are crucial in evaluating female fertility. On an HSG, submucosal fibroids  would appear as filling defects within the uterine cavity.

 

Ref: Page 440, Williams Gynecology 3rd editionQuestion ID:19156

questions.text: Which of the following is the gold standard technique for tubal evaluation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Laparoscopic evaluation

 

Explanation:

 

The following are tests done for tubal patency

 

  1. HSG (usually a preliminary test)
  2. Laparoscopic Chromotubation (Gold standard)
  3. Saline salpingography (better for intra uterine lesions)
  4. Others
    1. HyCoSy
    2. Falloposcopy

 

Let's review each option:

 

Option A. Hysterosalpingography (HSG): This is a radiographic technique where a contrast dye is injected into the uterine cavity, and X-ray images are taken to visualize the uterus and fallopian tubes. HSG is primarily used for evaluating the internal shape of the uterus and the patency of the fallopian tubes. While it's a commonly used first-line investigation for tubal assessment in infertility evaluations, it provides limited information about the external contour of the tubes and surrounding structures.

 

Option B. Laparoscopic chrompertubation: Laparoscopy is considered the gold standard for tubal evaluation. It's a minimally invasive surgical procedure that provides a direct view of the pelvic organs, including the fallopian tubes. Laparoscopy not only allows for the assessment of tubal patency (often combined with chromopertubation, where a dye is passed through the tubes) but also enables visualization of the outer aspects of the tubes and the detection of other pelvic pathologies like endometriosis, adhesions, or fibroids that might affect tubal function. Its main limitation is that it's an invasive procedure requiring anesthesia.

 

Option C. Saline Infusion Sonography (SIS): SIS involves the infusion of saline into the uterine cavity during ultrasound examination. This technique  can be used to asses tubal patency,  it also enhances the visualization of the uterine cavity and can be useful in detecting abnormalities like polyps or fibroids.

 

Option D. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI): MRI can provide detailed images of the pelvic organs, including the uterus and fallopian tubes, without using ionizing radiation. It's particularly useful in assessing uterine anomalies and some types of fibroids. However, MRI is less commonly used for direct assessment of tubal patency or minor tubal abnormalities compared to laparoscopy or HSG.

 

Educational Objective: Laparoscopic evaluation, as the gold standard, offers the most comprehensive assessment of the fallopian tubes and surrounding pelvic anatomy. However, other less invasive techniques like HSG and SIS also play important roles in initial assessments, especially in infertility workups. MRI, while offering excellent soft tissue contrast, is less specific for tubal patency

 

Page 441, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: Which day of the menstrual cycle should an HSG be done?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Day 8

 

Explanation:

 

  • HSG is a test for tubal patency
  • It also delineates the uterine cavity
  • It is best done between Day 5 – 10 (Before ovulation in the post menstrual period)
  • At this time, few intrauterine clots should remain to block tubal outflow or give the false impression of an intrauterine abnormality.
  • Furthermore, a woman theoretically has not ovulated or possibly conceived.
  • For this test, iodinated contrast medium is infused through an instrument (Leech Wilkinson cannula) placed into the uterus.
  • With fluoroscopy, dye is visually followed as it fills the uterine cavity, then the tubal lumen, and finally spills out of the tubal fimbria into the pelvic cavity.

 

Educational Objective: HSG should be performed after menstruation but before ovulation, to minimize the risk of infection, avoid interference from menstrual blood or a thickened endometrium, and to ensure that there is no risk of disturbing an early pregnancy.

 

Ref: Page 438, Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition

choices.text: Laparoscopy with chrompertubation
Saline infusion sonography
Chlamydia trachomatis antibody testing

questions.text: A 32-year woman presents with primary infertility. She has been trying to conceive for over a year with regular unprotected intercourse but has not been successful. On further evaluation, her menstrual cycles are regular with moderate flow and mild dysmenorrhoea and her partner’s semen analysis is normal. A tubal patency test is ordered. Which of the following test is most appropriate in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hysterosalpingography

 

Explanation:

 

  • The initial investigation of choice for tubal patency is an HSG
  • The best investigation for tubal patency is Laparoscopy with chrompertubation

 

Let's review each of the options provided:

 

Option A. Hysterosalpingography (HSG) (Correct Answer): HSG is a radiographic procedure where a contrast dye is injected into the uterine cavity and X-ray images are taken. It's often the first-line test for evaluating tubal patency in women with infertility, as it's less invasive than laparoscopy. HSG can reveal whether the fallopian tubes are open and can also provide information about the shape of the uterine cavity. It's particularly suitable in this scenario where there are no other major indications for laparoscopy.

 

Option B. Laparoscopy with Chromopertubation: This is a more invasive procedure. While it's considered the gold standard for evaluating tubal patency, it's typically reserved for cases where HSG results are inconclusive or when there's a suspicion of other pelvic pathology that needs direct visualization, like endometriosis or adhesions.

 

Option C. Saline Infusion Sonography (SIS): SIS involves the infusion of saline into the uterine cavity during an ultrasound exam. It's effective for evaluating the uterine cavity for abnormalities like polyps or fibroids but may not be as effective as HSG for assessing tubal patency.

 

Option D. Chlamydia trachomatis antibody testing: While testing for Chlamydia trachomatis antibodies can be important in infertility evaluations, particularly if there's a history suggesting a risk of pelvic inflammatory disease, it doesn't directly assess tubal patency. It can be used as an adjunct to other tests when determining the cause of infertility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In infertility:

 

  • The initial investigation of choice for tubal patency is an HSG
  • The best investigation for tubal patency is Laparoscopy with chrompertubation

 

Ref: Page 440, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Laparoscopy with chrompertubation

questions.text: A 38-year woman marries for the 2ndtime, her 1st husband having expired. She has a history of a D & C for a missed abortion with her 1st husband. She now reports to the gyn OPD with complaints of inability to conceive after trying for 1 year. She has regular periods. A pelvic ultrasound is normal. Husband semen analysis is normal. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Laparoscopy with chrompertubation

 

Explanation:

 

  • This is a patient with secondary infertility
  • One of the common causes of secondary infertility is tubal causes following PID
  • Tubal patency needs to be checked in this patient
  • Hence the best option is laparoscopic chrompertubation

 

Let's evaluate each option:

 

Option A. Ovulation Induction: This is typically considered when there is evidence of anovulation or irregular ovulation. However, in this case, the patient reports regular menstrual cycles, which suggests that she is likely ovulating normally.

 

Option B. Laparoscopy with Chromopertubation (Correct Answer): Given her history of a prior dilation and curettage (D&C), which can sometimes lead to intrauterine adhesions or other uterine abnormalities, and the fact that other basic fertility evaluations are normal, a laparoscopy with chromopertubation is a reasonable next step. This procedure allows for direct visualization of the pelvic organs and can assess for any adhesions, endometriosis, or other factors that could be contributing to infertility. Chromopertubation during laparoscopy will assess the patency of the fallopian tubes.

 

Option C. Endometrial Biopsy: This test is used to evaluate the health of the endometrium, often in cases of abnormal uterine bleeding or to assess for luteal phase defects. Given her history and current presentation, an endometrial biopsy might not be the most informative next step in the absence of specific indications for this test.

 

Option D. IVF (In Vitro Fertilization): IVF is a more advanced fertility treatment option and is often considered when other less invasive methods have failed, or when there is a clear indication for its use (such as blocked fallopian tubes, severe male factor infertility, etc.). Jumping straight to IVF without first assessing for other potential issues (like tubal patency or intrauterine adhesions) may be premature in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The key educational objective here is to understand the stepwise approach in managing infertility, especially in cases with a potentially complicated obstetric history.
  • Initial assessments should include semen analysis, ovulation confirmation, and an evaluation of the uterine cavity and tubal patency.
     

Ref: Page 430, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: Which of the following medications is used for achieving a pregnancy in a patient with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gonadotropins

 

Explanation:

 

  • In Hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism, the cause of anovulation is in the pituitary or hypothalamus.
  • Hence ovulation can be achieved by use of gonadotropins (FSH or LH)
  • In ovarian causes of anovulation lie PCOS, clomiphene citrate and letrozole is used
  • Estradiol is not an ovulation inducing agent

 

Let's review each of the options provided:

 

Option A. Estradiol: Estradiol plays a crucial role in the menstrual  cycle and is used in various hormonal therapies, it is not primarily used to induce ovulation.

 

Option B. Letrozole: Letrozole is an aromatase inhibitor that's often used for ovulation induction, particularly in cases of polycystic ovary syndrome .It works by reducing estrogen levels, which in turn stimulates the release of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH), promoting ovulation. However, it's not the primary choice for hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Option C. Gonadotropins (Correct Answer): Gonadotropins, which include FSH and LH, are the primary treatment for hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. This condition is characterized by low levels of these hormones due to problems in the hypothalamus or pituitary gland. Administering gonadotropins directly stimulates the ovaries to produce eggs, making it the most effective treatment for inducing ovulation in women with this condition.

 

Option D. Clomiphene Citrate (Clomid): Clomiphene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) used commonly to induce ovulation in women with certain types of infertility, particularly when the issue is anovulation or oligoovulation. Clomiphene works by blocking estrogen receptors, which increases the release of FSH and LH. However, in hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, where FSH and LH are deficient, clomiphene is not typically effective .

 

Educational Objective: In the case of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, where there's a deficiency in gonadotropins due to hypothalamic or pituitary dysfunction, direct administration of gonadotropins is the most effective approach.

 

Ref: Page 481, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: A 28-year-old obese female who is seeking pregnancy is recently diagnosed with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). Which of the following should be recommended as first-line management for her anovulation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Letrozole

 

Explanation:

 

  • All the options mentioned will help in ovulation in PCOS
  • Lifestyle management (Weight loss if BMI is high + exercise) is the PRIMARY mode of management
  • The 1st line ovulation induction agents are
    • Letrozole
    • Clomiphene citrate
  • Amongst these 2, the recent ESHRE guidelines says that Letrozole is to be preferred over clomiphene in PCOS.
  • Gonadotropins may be used as second line agents for ovulation induction after oral drugs. Insulin sensitizing agents such as metformin and myoinositol are also used in PCOS patients as adjunctive treatment.

   

Let's review each option separately:

 

Option A. Gonadotropins: These are injectable hormones (FSH and LH) used to stimulate ovulation. While effective, they are typically not the first line of treatment for PCOS due to the increased risk of multiple pregnancies and ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome. They are often considered when other treatments have failed.

 

Option B. Clomiphene Citrate: This is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that has traditionally been used as the first-line treatment for inducing ovulation in women with PCOS. It works by blocking estrogen receptors in the brain, which increases the release of FSH and LH, thereby stimulating ovulation.

 

Option C. Letrozole (Correct Answer): Letrozole, an aromatase inhibitor, has recently become preferred over clomiphene citrate for the first-line management of anovulation in women with PCOS, particularly in obese patients. Studies have shown that letrozole is more effective in inducing ovulation in women with PCOS.

 

Option D. Insulin-Sensitizing Agents: These agents, such as metformin, are used to improve insulin resistance, a common feature in PCOS. While they can help in regulating menstrual cycles and improving the efficacy of ovulation-inducing agents, they are generally not used as a standalone first-line treatment

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Letrozole has emerged as a preferred first-line treatment due to its higher efficacy in inducing ovulation and also due to mono-follicular development compared to clomiphene citrate, especially in obese patients with PCOS.

 

Ref: https://www.eshre.eu/Guidelines-and-Legal/Guidelines/Polycystic-Ovary-Syndrome

choices.text: Surgical therapy is preferred over medical therapy.
During pregnancy, cabergoline is preferred over bromocriptine.
Clomiphene citrate may be ineffective for ovulation induction.
Dopamine-agonist therapy should be increased once pregnancy is achieved.

questions.text: In women with hyperprolactinemia caused by a pituitary micro-prolactinoma, which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clomiphene citrate may be ineffective for ovulation induction.

 

Explanation:

 

  • If hyperprolactinemia is found, then physiologic, pharmacologic, or other secondary causes of hormone hypersecretion are sought
  • Dopamine agonists are the primary treatment of hyperprolactinemia.
  • Surgical therapies are only considered with prolactin-secreting adenomas resistant to medical therapy.
  • During pregnancy, if hyperprolactinemia is not associated with a pituitary lesion or a lesion is less than 10 mm (microadenoma), then dopamine-agonist therapy is stopped because the tumor expansion risk is low
  • Bromocriptine is preferred in pregnancy.

 

Let's evaluate each option:

 

Option A. Surgical therapy is preferred over medical therapy: This is generally not true. Medical therapy, typically with dopamine agonists like bromocriptine or cabergoline, is the first-line treatment for hyperprolactinemia, including that caused by micro-prolactinomas. These medications are effective in reducing prolactin levels and often lead to tumor shrinkage. Surgical therapy is usually reserved for cases where medical therapy is ineffective or not tolerated.

 

Option B. During pregnancy, cabergoline is preferred over bromocriptine: Actually, bromocriptine is generally preferred over cabergoline during pregnancy. Bromocriptine has a longer track record and more data supporting its safety in pregnancy

 

Option C. Clomiphene citrate may be ineffective for ovulation induction (Correct Answer): This is true. Clomiphene citrate is an ovulation induction agent that works by blocking estrogen receptors, leading to an increase in the release of FSH and LH. However, in the presence of elevated prolactin levels, as seen in hyperprolactinemia, the effectiveness of clomiphene may be diminished. Therefore, normalizing prolactin levels with dopamine agonists is often necessary before or in conjunction with using clomiphene.

 

Option D. Dopamine-agonist therapy should be increased once pregnancy is achieved: This is not typically recommended. In fact, dopamine agonist therapy is often discontinued once pregnancy is confirmed in women with micro-prolactinomas. This is because the risk of tumor growth during pregnancy is low, and the safety of continued use of these drugs during pregnancy is not fully established.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • First-line treatment of hyper-prolactinemia with a mico-adenoma typically involves medical therapy with dopamine agonists, which are effective in lowering prolactin levels and can restore ovulatory function.

 

Ref: Page 450, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Higher ovulation rate
Lower multiple pregnancy rate
Lower ovarian hyperstimulation rate
Greater negative effect on the endometrium

questions.text: Compared with clomiphene citrate therapy, gonadotropin therapy has which of the following characteristics?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Higher ovulation rate

 

Explanation:

 

  • Gonadotropins are usually 2nd line drugs for ovulation induction
  • They are preferred in hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism
  • They have a higher ovulation rate and a higher multiple pregnancy rate also.
  • Women with PCOS have ovaries highly sensitive to gonadotropin stimulation. They have a higher risk of excessive ovarian response and of multifetal pregnancy than those with normal ovaries.
  • Unlike clomiphene, they do not have a negative effect on the endometrium.

 

Let's examine each option separately :

 

Option A. Higher Ovulation Rate (Correct Answer): This is because gonadotropins more directly stimulate the ovaries, whereas clomiphene citrate works indirectly by blocking estrogen receptors, which in turn promotes the release of FSH and LH.

 

Option B. Lower Multiple Pregnancy Rate: This is not true for gonadotropin therapy. In fact, gonadotropin therapy has a higher risk of multiple pregnancies compared to clomiphene citrate. This is due to the more potent and direct ovarian stimulation with gonadotropins, which can lead to the development of multiple follicles.

 

Option C. Lower Ovarian Hyperstimulation Rate: Gonadotropin therapy actually has a higher risk of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) compared to clomiphene citrate. The ovaries become swollen and painful, and it is more likely with stimulation of the ovaries by gonadotropins.

 

Option D. Greater Negative Effect on the Endometrium: Clomiphene citrate, not gonadotropin therapy, is more commonly associated with a negative effect on the endometrium.

 

Educational Objective: While gonadotropin therapy often results in a higher ovulation rate, it also carries a higher risk of multiple pregnancies and ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome. Clomiphene citrate, on the other hand, is associated with a lower risk of these complications but can have a negative impact on the endometrium.

 

Ref: Page 479, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: The typical starting dose is 100 mg.
It is classified as a category X drug by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA).
It can be initiated on the second day of the menstrual cycle.
Most pregnancies will occur during the first three treatment cycles.

questions.text: Which of the following is LEAST likely to be true regarding clomiphene citrate therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The typical starting dose is 100 mg.

 

Explanation:

 

  • Clomiphene citrate is an anti-estrogen
  • It is used in ovulation induction in anovulatory women (PCOS)
  • It is given as a starting dose of 50mg from Day2 to Day 6 followed by an follicular imaging scan from the 10th day of the period
  • It is contra-indicated in pregnancy (FDA Category X)

 

Let's evaluate each option:

 

Option A. The typical starting dose is 100 mg (Correct Answer): This is the least likely to be true. The typical starting dose of clomiphene citrate is usually 50 mg per day, not 100 mg. The dose may be increased in subsequent cycles if there is no response, but starting at a higher dose increases the risk of side effects, including the chance of multiple pregnancies.

 

Option B. It is classified as a category X drug by the FDA: Clomiphene citrate is actually classified as FDA pregnancy category X, meaning that it should not be used during pregnancy. The drug is used to induce ovulation, but if a woman becomes pregnant, the use of clomiphene should be discontinued due to potential risks to the fetus.

 

Option C. It can be initiated on the second day of the menstrual cycle: This is true. Clomiphene citrate is often initiated on the second, third, fourth, or fifth day of the menstrual cycle.

 

Option D. Most pregnancies will occur during the first three treatment cycles: This is true. The majority of pregnancies achieved with clomiphene citrate occur within the first three cycles of treatment. If conception has not occurred after this time, the likelihood of success with continued use of clomiphene decreases, and other treatment options may be considered.

 

Educational Objective: The standard initial dose of clomiphene citrate is 50 mg and most successful treatments occur within the first three cycles. Additionally, understanding its FDA pregnancy category X classification is crucial for ensuring its safe use.

 

Ref: Page 450, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Etiology of her infertility
Number of embryos transferred

questions.text: A 38-year-old with infertility secondary to tubal blockage just underwent in vitro fertilization (IVF). Her peak estradiol was 4500 pg/mL. Seventeen oocytes were retrieved, and two embryos were transferred. She conceived with a singleton gestation. She developed ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome. Which of the following was a predisposing factor in developing ovarian hyperstimulation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Estradiol level

 

Explanation:

 

Risk factors for OHSS include

 

  • Young age (< 35y)
  • Low BMI
  • PCOS
  • History of allergy/ atopy
  • High serum estradiol
  • Previous h/o OHSS
  • Multiple follicles (PCOS)
  • High dose/ repeated doses of hCG
  • Pregnancy

 

Let's examine each option in relation to the predisposition to OHSS:

 

Option A. Her Age: While age can impact various aspects of fertility and responses to fertility treatments, it is not typically considered a direct predisposing factor for the development of OHSS. Women of varying ages can develop OHSS, and it's more related to the response to the ovarian stimulation rather than age per se.

 

Option B. Estradiol Level (Correct Answer): A high estradiol level is indeed a key predisposing factor for OHSS. A peak estradiol level of 4500 pg/mL, as mentioned in the scenario, is significantly high and can be associated with an increased risk of developing OHSS. This is due to the large number of growing follicles producing estradiol, which can lead to increased vascular permeability and the symptoms associated with OHSS.

 

Option C. Etiology of Her Infertility: The underlying cause of infertility (in this case, tubal blockage) is generally not a direct risk factor for OHSS

 

Option D. Number of Embryos Transferred: The number of embryos transferred does not directly predispose to OHSS. OHSS is related to the ovarian response to stimulation during the IVF cycle, not the embryo transfer process

 

Educational Objective: High estradiol levels during IVF cycles are a significant risk factor for OHSS, as they reflect a robust ovarian response to stimulation.

 

Ref: Page no 456, Williams Gynecology 3rd editio

choices.text: Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)

questions.text: Which of the following hormones is thought to play a major role in ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)

 

Explanation:

 

  • OHSS is characterized by multiple follicular development and ovarian enlargement following hCG stimulation.
  • It occurs mostly in IVF due to controlled ovarian hyperstimulation (COH) but can also happen with simple ovulation induction
  • It is an iatrogenic and potentially a life-threatening complication of COH
  • hCG and VEGF have been implicated in the etiology of OHSS

 

Let's review each option:

 

Option A. Progesterone: Progesterone is a hormone produced by the corpus luteum after ovulation and during pregnancy. While it plays a critical role in the menstrual cycle and maintaining pregnancy, it is not primarily implicated in the development of OHSS.

 

Option B. Luteinizing Hormone (LH): LH is involved in the natural ovulation process. It triggers ovulation and the development of the corpus luteum. While controlled ovarian hyperstimulation often involves drugs that mimic LH action, LH itself is not the primary hormone implicated in OHSS.

 

Option C. Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG) (Correct Answer): hCG is the hormone primarily implicated in OHSS. In fertility treatments, hCG is often used to mimic the natural LH surge to trigger ovulation. However, its use, especially in high doses or in sensitive individuals, can lead to OHSS. hCG stimulates the ovaries to produce more estrogen, leading to ovarian enlargement and increased vascular permeability, which are key features of OHSS.

 

Option D. Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH): FSH is used in fertility treatments to stimulate the development of ovarian follicles. While it plays a role in controlled ovarian hyperstimulation, it is not directly responsible for the development of OHSS.

 

Educational Objective: HCG plays a central role in the development of OHSS, particularly following its administration in the context of controlled ovarian hyperstimulation (COH).

 

Ref: Page 456, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Urinary human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)
Recombinant human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)

questions.text: If concern for ovarian hyperstimulation is present during ovulation induction, which of the following can be used to induce the endogenous luteinizing hormone (LH) surge?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist

 

Explanation:

 

OHSS can be prevented by the following ways:

 

  • Use of GnRH antagonists (instead of GnRH agonists) for down regulation
  • Low starting dose of gonadotropins in high-risk women
  • Metformin cotreatment during gonadotropin stimulation in women with PCOS or at high risk of OHSS
  • Close monitoring of the superovulation cycles using TVS and serum estradiol estimation
  • Replacing hCG with leuprolide (GnRH agonist) as a maturation trigger (i.e. induce the LH surge)
  • To withhold ovulatory dose of hCG in susceptible cases and to cancel the cycle or to delay the dose of hCG injection (coasting)
  • Cryopreservation of oocytes or embryos for future use
  • Aspiration of immature oocytes and in vitro maturation (IVM)
  • Progesterone should be used for luteal phase support instead of hCG
  • Cabergoline and albumin have a role in reducing the incidence of OHSS in those at high risk

 

Let's review each option:

 

Option A. Urinary Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG): This is commonly used to induce ovulation, as it acts like the body's natural luteinizing hormone (LH) surge. However, hCG can increase the risk of OHSS, especially in patients who are overly responsive to ovarian stimulation.

 

Option B. Recombinant Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG): Similar to urinary hCG, recombinant hCG is used to induce ovulation but can also contribute to the development of OHSS. Both forms of hCG have a longer duration of action, which can exacerbate OHSS in high-risk patients.

 

Option C. Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH) Agonist (Correct Answer): In patients at risk for OHSS, a GnRH agonist can be used to trigger ovulation. Unlike hCG, GnRH agonists cause a shorter and more physiologic LH surge, which can induce ovulation with a lower risk of OHSS. This is particularly beneficial in patients undergoing controlled ovarian stimulation as part of an IVF cycle who have a high number of follicles.

 

Option D. Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH) Antagonist: GnRH antagonists are used during ovarian stimulation protocols to prevent premature ovulation. They do not trigger the LH surge.

 

Educational Objective: In patients at high risk for OHSS, using a GnRH agonist to induce a more physiologic LH surge is a safer alternative compared to hCG, as it significantly reduces the risk of OHSS.

 

Ref: Page 456, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Infertility secondary to anovulation
Infertility secondary to diminished ovarian reserve
Infertility secondary to bilateral distal fallopian tube occlusion
Infertility secondary to the male partner’s severe oligospermia

questions.text: Which of the following infertility scenarios would warrant intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Infertility secondary to the male partner’s severe oligospermia

 

Explanation:

 

  • ICSI is intra cytoplasmic sperm injection
  • It is a variation of IVF and is most applicable to male actor infertility.
  • During the micromanipulation technique of ICSI, cumulus cells surrounding an ovum are enzymatically digested, and a single sperm is directly injected through the zona pellucida and oocyte cell membrane.
  • Pregnancy rates with ICSI are comparable with those achieved with IVF or other causes of infertility.

 

Let's review each option:

 

Option A. Infertility secondary to Anovulation: Anovulation, the absence of ovulation, is often treated with medications that induce ovulation, such as clomiphene citrate or gonadotropins. ICSI is not typically indicated in cases where the primary issue is anovulation, as the main challenge is to produce a viable egg, not the fertilization process itself.

 

Option B. Infertility secondary to Diminished Ovarian Reserve: While IVF may be recommended in such cases to maximize the chance of fertilization, ICSI is not necessarily indicated unless there is also a concurrent male factor infertility.

 

Option C. Infertility secondary to Bilateral Distal Fallopian Tube Occlusion: When the fallopian tubes are blocked, particularly at the distal end (farther from the uterus), IVF is the usual treatment of choice because it bypasses the fallopian tubes altogether. ICSI may be added if there is an additional factor of male infertility.

 

Option D. Infertility secondary to the Male Partner’s Severe Oligospermia (Correct Answer): Severe oligospermia, characterized by a very low sperm count, is a classic indication for ICSI. In such cases, the chances of sperm naturally fertilizing an egg are significantly reduced. ICSI addresses this by directly injecting a single sperm into the egg, thus bypassing the need for a large number of motile sperm.

 

Educational Objective: ICSI is particularly beneficial in scenarios where male factor infertility, such as severe oligospermia, is a significant contributing factor to the couple's infertility.

 

ReF: Page 465, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Oocyte in vitro maturation
Intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI)

questions.text: Which of the following assisted reproductive technologies (ART) techniques is shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Embryo biopsy

 

Explanation:

 

  • This is an image showing embryo biopsy which is done in pre-implantation genetic diagnosis
  • During this technique, cells are removed from a developing embryo.
  • Multiple options exist regarding biopsy timing and genetic material source.
    • Biopsy of the first and second polar body has the advantage of avoiding cell removal from the developing embryo, but the disadvantage is that genetic abnormalities of paternal origin are not detected.
    • Biopsy of cleavage-stage embryos (6- to 8-cell stage) allows evaluation of both maternal and paternal contribution to the genome
    • Biopsy of tropho-ectoderm at the blastocyst stage

 

Let us look at each option separately:

 

Option A. Embryo Biopsy: This technique involves removing one or more cells from an embryo to test for genetic conditions before transferring the embryo to the uterus. It is often used in conjunction with preimplantation genetic testing (PGT) to identify embryos with genetic abnormalities or specific inherited disorders.

 

Option B. Assisted Hatching: This technique involves making a small hole in the zona pellucida (the outer layer of the embryo) to assist the embryo in breaking free during the process of implantation. It's sometimes used to improve the chances of implantation, particularly in certain groups of patients such as older women or those with previous failed IVF cycles.

 

Option C. Oocyte In Vitro Maturation (IVM): In this process, immature eggs are collected from the ovaries and matured in the laboratory. This is different from conventional IVF, where medication is used to mature the eggs inside the ovaries before they are collected.

 

Option D. Intracytoplasmic Sperm Injection (ICSI): ICSI involves injecting a single sperm directly into an egg to achieve fertilization. It's used especially in cases of severe male factor infertility, where sperm may have difficulty penetrating the egg on their own.

 

Educational Objective: Each technique addresses different challenges in the fertility treatment process, from genetic testing of embryos (embryo biopsy) and facilitating implantation (assisted hatching), to managing immature eggs (oocyte IVM) and overcoming male infertility issues (ICSI).

 

Ref: Page 466, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Premature ovarian failure

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication for gestational surrogacy
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mullerian agenesis

 

Explanation:

 

  • Mullerian agenesis is an example of absolute uterine factor infertility which is an indication for gestational surrogacy.
  • Gestational surrogacy is a variation to IVF in which a fertilized egg is placed into the uterus of a surrogate rather than into the “intended mother.”
  • Indications:
    • Women with uncorrectable uterine factors
    • Those in whom pregnancy would pose significant health risks
    • h/o repetitive unexplained abortions

 

Thus, option B: Mullerian agenesis is an indication for surrogacy.

 

Let's review each option to determine the most appropriate indication for gestational surrogacy:

 

Option A. Tubercular Salpingitis: This condition involves inflammation of the fallopian tubes due to tuberculosis, which can lead to infertility. Women with tubercular salpingitis may be treated with anti-tubercular therapy and potentially IVF if the fallopian tubes are significantly damaged.

 

Option B. Mullerian Agenesis (Correct Answer): Mullerian agenesis, also known as Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome, is a condition where a woman is born without a uterus or with an underdeveloped uterus. Since these women cannot carry a pregnancy themselves, gestational surrogacy is a viable option for them to have a child genetically related to them (using their own eggs, if ovaries are functional, and a partner's or donor's sperm).

 

Option C. Azoospermia: This is a male infertility condition where there is no sperm in the ejaculate. Azoospermia itself is not an indication for gestational surrogacy but rather for male fertility treatments, such as surgical sperm retrieval combined with IVF/ICSI (Intracytoplasmic Sperm Injection).

 

Option D. Premature Ovarian Failure: This condition occurs when a woman's ovaries stop functioning normally before the age of 40. While it can lead to infertility, it's not a direct indication for gestational surrogacy. Women with premature ovarian failure may consider options like IVF using donor eggs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Gestational surrogacy is particularly relevant for women who are unable to carry a pregnancy, such as those with Mullerian agenesis.
  • In contrast, conditions affecting the fallopian tubes, male factor infertility, or ovarian function may require different assisted reproductive technologies, but not necessarily surrogacy.

 

Ref: Page no 465, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Hysteroscopic bilateral tubal cannulation
Ovulation induction

questions.text: A patient comes to your OPD for infertility treatment. Her HSG shows the following picture. What would be the best management for her?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hysteroscopic bilateral tubal cannulation

 

Explanation:

 

  • This is an HSG showing a bilateral cornual block (block at the proximal portion as the tubes cannot be seen at all).
  • Cornual block (proximal tubal obstructions) can be managed with proximal tubal catheterization and cannulation (via hysteroscopy or HSG) with 85% success in restoring tubal patency.
  • Distal tubal occlusion is usually secondary to inflammatory conditions, endometriosis and previous h/o surgery. If < 35y, microsurgery can be considered (Tuboplasty). IF > 35 y, IVF should be considered. The choice of treatment largely depends on the specific findings of the HSG:

 

Let us look at each option

 

Option A. IVF (In Vitro Fertilization): IVF is often considered when there are severe tubal abnormalities (such as bilateral tubal blockage), severe male factor infertility, or when other fertility treatments have failed. If the HSG shows severely damaged or blocked fallopian tubes that are unlikely to be successfully treated with surgery, IVF may be the recommended option.

 

Option B. Tuboplasty: This surgical procedure is used to repair or reconstruct the fallopian tubes. It's considered in cases where there's tubal damage or blockage that is amenable to surgical correction. The success of tuboplasty depends on the location and extent of the tubal damage.

 

Option C. Hysteroscopic Bilateral Tubal Cannulation: This procedure is used in cases of proximal tubal blockage (blockage near the uterus). It involves the use of a hysteroscope and a cannula to open up the blocked segments of the fallopian tubes. If the HSG shows proximal tubal blockage, this procedure can be an effective treatment.

 

Option D. Ovulation Induction: This treatment is used when the primary cause of infertility is anovulation. If the HSG shows that the fallopian tubes are open and the main issue is a lack of ovulation, ovulation induction might be the appropriate treatment.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • HSG is a valuable diagnostic tool in evaluating the fallopian tubes and the uterine cavity, and its findings are critical in guiding the appropriate management approach, whether surgical or medical.
  • Hysteroscopic Bilateral Tubal Cannulation is used in cases of proximal tubal blockage (blockage near the uterus).

 

Ref: Page 1158, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology 15th edition

choices.text: Chocolate cyst
Broad ligament fibroid

questions.text: A 28-year women with history of an ectopic pregnancy presents with subfertility of 3 years. She complains of recurrent vaginal discharge. A transvaginal ultrasound reveals the following. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hydrosalpinx

 

Explanation: 

 

The above scenario is that of a hydrosalpinx. Points in favor of this are:

 

  • H/o ectopic pregnancy 
  • H/o subfertility
  • Recurrent discharge PV 
  • USG showing a retort shaped hypoechoic collection suggestive of hydrosalpinx

 

Let's review each option in the context of the provided information:

 

Option A. Ovarian Malignancy: This diagnosis would be suggested by the presence of complex masses or irregularities in the ovaries. However, ovarian malignancies often present with additional clinical signs and symptoms, and they might have more complex features on ultrasound than what is typically seen in cases of hydrosalpinx.

 

Option B. Chocolate Cyst (Endometrioma): A chocolate cyst or endometrioma is associated with endometriosis and typically appears as a cystic ovarian mass with homogenous, low-level internal echoes on ultrasound, due to the presence of old blood.

 

Option C. Hydrosalpinx (Correct Answer): Hydrosalpinx refers to the accumulation of fluid in a fallopian tube, often resulting from past infection or inflammation, such as from an ectopic pregnancy. On ultrasound, it appears as an elongated, fluid-filled sac typically adjacent to the ovary. Given the patient's history of ectopic pregnancy and the description of the ultrasound findings, hydrosalpinx is the most likely diagnosis.

 

Option D. Broad Ligament Fibroid: A fibroid in the broad ligament would typically appear as a solid mass on ultrasound, often with a characteristic whorled pattern. It is distinct from a fluid-filled structure like a hydrosalpinx.

 

Educational Objective: A hydrosalpinx, which is a fluid-filled dilation of a fallopian tube, often results from previous pelvic infection or inflammation and has distinct ultrasound features (elongated, retort shaped fluid-filled sac typically adjacent to the ovary.

 

Ref: Page 566, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology, 15th edition

choices.text: Basal body temperature chart

questions.text: A 28-year-old P1L1 woman complains of significant dysmenorrhea & dyspareunia. She has menses every month & has no past history of any abdominal surgery or any vaginal infection. Which of the following tests would most likely identify the etiology of the infertility in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Laparoscopy

 

Explanation:

 

  • This is likely a case of endometriosis
  • Regular periods rules out ovarian causes like PCOS; hence basal body temperature and progesterone assay are not essential to identify pathology in this patient
  • HSG is useful for tubal pathology, but endometriosis is best diagnosed by laparoscopy
  • C/F of endometriosis are: 5 D’s
    • Dysmenorrhea
    • Dyspareunia
    • Dull aching abdominal pain
    • Dysfertility (Infertility)
    • Dyschezia

 

Let's review each option separately:

 

Option A. Laparoscopy: Given the symptoms of significant dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia, with a normal menstrual cycle and no history of abdominal surgery or vaginal infection, endometriosis is a likely differential diagnosis. Laparoscopy is the gold standard for the diagnosis of endometriosis. It allows direct visualization of the pelvic organs and the identification, biopsy, and potentially treatment of endometriotic lesions

 

Option B. Basal Body Temperature Chart: While a basal body temperature chart can help in understanding ovulation patterns, it is less likely to identify the cause of dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia.

 

Option C. Hysterosalpingogram (HSG): It can be used to identify uterine abnormalities or tubal blockage but is less effective in diagnosing conditions like endometriosis, which more commonly cause dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia.

 

Option D. Progesterone Assay: This test measures the level of progesterone to confirm ovulation, but it would not directly identify the cause of her pain or infertility, especially in the context of a regular menstrual cycle.

 

Educational Objective: The appropriate diagnostic approach for a woman presenting with dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and infertility is  laparoscopy . As it is the most informative test in this scenario, especially to rule out or confirm endometriosis or other pelvic pathologies

 

ReF:  Page no 512, 516, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology 15th edition
